awd_titl_txt: Gauge Theory and Trivalent Graphs in Three-Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
In this research project, the principal investigator will continue work that aims to provide a human-readable proof of the four color map theorem.  The four color map theorem was first proved in 1976 by Appel and Haken; the proof involved a huge amount of case checking, so much so that the only feasible method of attack was via computer.  This machine-assisted proof, however, cannot be directly checked by a human.  Although there have been some subsequent simplifications and clarifications, the general brute-force approach has seemed to be the only line of attack.  The four color theorem can be rephrased, though, as a question about the topology of three-dimensional manifolds, and in particular new tools inspired by high energy physics give novel ways to approach a conceptual proof of the four color theorem.  This project explores and develops these new insights.

The principal investigator and collaborator define a version of instanton Floer homology for trivalent graphs embedded in three-manifolds. This theory enables them to place the four color map theorem firmly in the context of gauge-theory-inspired invariants of three-manifolds. They have proved a fundamental non-vanishing theorem for this Floer homology group, reducing the four color map theorem to a question about computing this invariant for general planar graphs.  They are developing new tools for the computation of these and related invariants, and they have discovered a spectral sequence relevant to this computation.  The collapse of the spectral sequence for planar graphs would imply the four color theorem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI together with Peter Kronheimer has developed novel tools to explore and elucidate theoretical models of space-time.  Mathematically space time is modeled as four dimensional "manifold" locally there 4 directions- the usual 3 spacial directions and a fourth time direction.  The models from physics allow that these local four dimensional patches and glue together to give topologically complicated models.  Ideas from high energy physics such as the Yang-Mills equations used to model quarks and the Seiberg-Witten equations can be used to give delicate constraints on the possible topologies of these models, often these tools provide the only known way of prove these constraints. The PI and his students have done a lot of work in elucidating the application of these tools, inventing new related tools.  The PI and his students have presented this work both with in the US at many institutions of higher learning as well as given summer schools and courses to introduce these ideas to the next generation of scientists. 

 

A surprising aspect of this work is a connection to the four color map problem.  In 1975 Appel and Haken famously proved the long standing conjecture that every planar map can be colored using at most four colors so that no two countries which share a border are colored the same. The  Appel and Haken proof is notorious for the use of computers as a necessary tool.  They reduced the problem to a large finite list of cases that require a computer to be check.  In the intervening 50 years no human readable proof has been found. It turns out that the tools that PI and his collaborators are developing give a potential line of attack for this problem.  The key to this line is computing the number of states of a certain topological quantum field theory (TQFT) model that uses the borders of the maps  as input. On the one hand its is known from earlier work that any such TQFT arising from a map has at least one non-trivial state and for many maps the number states determines the number of four colorings. The PI and collaborators are trying to develop tools that would allow the computation of the number of states in general and if the pattern holds this would lead  to human readable proof to the four color map theorem.
